more_info: We’ll start our journey at the very beginning when Patrick was just a wee baby.
You are playing on the beach with Patrick when you notice a strange ship near the shore. Shiver me timbers! It’s pirates! You try to run but it’s too late. You are both captured.
Baa! You and Patrick are taken to Ireland where you are sold into slavery and made to look after sheep.
The lonely life of mud, bleating and woolly friends is not for Patrick. One night, a voice tells him it is time to leave Ireland. You both flee to the sea where you board a ship and make your escape.

He’s back!! After years of religious study, Patrick returns to Ireland to spread the word of Christianity among the population. You are particularly impressed by his legendary use of a shamrock to explain the holy trinity.

Uh-oh, this lady doesn’t look too happy! St. Brigid is complaining that women have to wait far too long for men to propose! In order to keep the peace, Patrick decrees that women may propose to men on the last day of February in a leap year.
What’s all hiss then? It’s the greatest St. Patrick legend of all, that’s what. You watch in amazement as Patrick delivers a hillside sermon which drives all of Ireland’s snakes into the sea!
Hurrah! The good word has been spread and the snakes are banished. It’s time to head to Paddy’s Bar, where the Guinness is flowing. First, one last chance to earn a shamrock.
He’s a sharp cookie! Patrick combines Christian and pagan symbology to help win over new followers to his preaching. This includes introducing the Celtic cross to Ireland.
